meta_data.title: The Pope Said What?! Current Event Response Episode.

Right, right. But church leaders, that is treating him as a politician. And if that's all the Pope
is, we need to be clear on that. Yeah. Rather than an authority. Right. But we don't even treat
politicians like that. It's almost like a celebrity. Yep. You know, like what he says in
his personal life is like, we're like off the record. Yeah. Which he wasn't technically off the
record, but you know. So one, I think this could easily be very confusing to people. The fact that,
okay, religion can change this much. But like you can be, no, no, this is absolutely not what we
teach. We do not teach that all religions are just like languages, etc. Right. That's one.
That's confusing. If you then come along later and go like, no, just kidding. That actually is fine.
You can actually be the Pope and believe that. Like, oh, okay. Well, you can be the Pope and believe
it anyway. So that's one. But two, I actually think it's a problem because it oversimplifies
the concept of religion in a way that is inappropriate. And it's, I think it's really
almost insulting to people who really are searching, who really are deconstructing and
trying to reconstruct to go, I'm, I'm trying to discover and trying to unpack what is the truth
here. And, and what you're telling me now is either there is no truth or they are all truth.
Mm hmm.
And that, that's very confusing as well. So in other words, even if they contradict each other,
they're real still, they're still really the same thing. And so there is no such thing as abstract
truth. Um, that seems super confusing to me as well. And then finally, like you said,
the issue of these religions do not coordinate.
There's like from a logical standpoint, just looking at them. That is right.
They don't, they don't, they don't coexist perfectly. There are senses in which they do
there. Things are the same. It isn't that they all contradict in every way. And I think that's a
healthy way to come at that, by the way. I think, let me see, as Lewis talked about that years ago,
that there is a totally appropriate way to, um, to understand, of course, some religions are closer
to the truth than the other. And, and we're not perfect in our understanding of even our religion.
We, we humbly are willing to, able and willing to accept that. But that doesn't mean that things
that contradict each other are, um, are still the same thing. They are equally valid. And that to me
is disturbing and confusing. If not insulting. Yeah. I think, I think it's a good delineation to
make. There's, there's a difference between finding common ground with other people in order
to have beneficial conversations with them. Like that's one thing. Um, but that's not the same as,
um, admitting that all truth is equal. All of it is the same. Basically it's all just a different
version. Like those are two different, they seem similar in passing, but they're not, you know,
right. And I think one is helpful and appropriate for Christians. And then the other, like you're
saying is not even like on just like scrolling through Reddit, a lot of Catholics are really
frustrated by this. Cause they're like, why does it matter that I'm a Catholic? Like from the
Pope's perspective, um, you know, like why just asking those questions of like, why does it matter
to pick anything? Um, you know, why does it matter to seek truth at all? Yeah. If I can pick
anything or if I don't, and another, another thing was saying, like this person was making, uh,
this is a, the Catholic world report.
And it was saying when the Pope says all religions are path to God, I think we need to cut him some
slack since it in context, what he was, uh, alluding to were the major higher religions of
the world, much of which he goes on to specifically name some seek some Muslim, some Hindu, some
Christian. So no, I do not think the Pope would view bail worship, Moloch worship, and modern
Satanism has passed to God. The word all in this context is one of those ambiguities we often see
when the Pope speaks extemporaneously. And I think that it needs to be interpreted charitably
in its context, but I'm like, but that's not what he said. Even, even so, I'm totally happy to say
the only ones he meant were seek Muslim, Hindu, Christian, right? Okay. Right. So I would just
love to hear him teach a seminar on how to integrate those. Um, and I have how they're
all able to be true. Yeah. How they're all able to be true simultaneously, how they're able to
be paths to the same God. When the people who the person, the person or persons they describe as God
aren't the same. I mean, it's, that's a, they are more or less correct. Like that's a, uh, more or
less true. And I would, again, so for him to come back, I think it would be intriguing if he had
come back and said, um, Hey, I just, just to be clear on this, I think all of these are an effort
to find God. And I honor that. And, and yet at the same time, I would say, obviously only Catholicism
is the only trustworthy source or like different ways he could talk about this, but it is intriguing.
And I just, for me, from a, from a deconstruction reconstruction perspective, it is, to the thought
of is, so if I am someone in the midst of deconstruction, the main problems for me would be
if this feels dishonest or insulting, um, or, or defeating maybe even like, like that it's like,
I don't even fully, I don't even understand how this, like how any of this works, but it feels
insulting. Like, so you're saying the fact that your faith has these contradictions, your answer
to that is like, I don't own them and I don't have to explain them. And if I was a, an atheist or,
or, you know, that version of skeptic, I would be like, that's yeah, good try. You don't get out of
it that easily. Yeah, it doesn't seem like a reasonable thing. Um, and yeah. And then the,
then it's like, so you're just acknowledging, are you admitting and owning that your religion
is not reasonable? Is that what you're telling me? Because then own that and then we can be
done with it. And I can just accept that it's an unreasonable faith that you're claiming. I'm
supposed to accept contradictions on the face of it and go, okay, cool. So you just don't believe in
anything reasonable or true. And I, so I, this is why I disagree with this. It's not because I
don't like, seek religion, the Muslim religion or the Hindu religion, though I probably would
actually do them kind of in that order. Um, I actually think the seek religion is fascinating.
I love the seek religion. It's amazing how many Americans think the seek are Muslims. Did you guys
ever see, um, um, Annie as a kid or anything? So, uh, Punjab is a seek, uh, not, not Muslim. And in
fact, the seek are considered themselves ancestral enemies of Muslims. Like it's not a, they don't,
they don't play well together in ways that are even beyond some of the others.
Which that was, that was what I was also thinking is like, okay,
I wonder if he, if he is playing to a specific crowd, if the, because I don't know the full
context of who he was talking to, but it's like, to me, those groups probably wouldn't be like,
you know what, he's right. Like to me, a, a Sikh, a Muslim and a Hindu, they are so,
and I'm, I understand I'm generalizing here, but most of them would be convinced that they're the
way to go. But in a very religious way, it's like, well, we're right though. Right. Am I, am I
saying the Hindu, the Hindu only the seek faith, I'd have to research the seek faith again to
understand what its view is on exclusivity. I feel like it may not be a super exclusive.
Okay. So it might be better. It might be more open. Um, although again, probably not with Islam is
Hinduism is certainly an open religion. Although you, I say that and know that like, wow, there,
it's, there are a bunch of the, the conservative, if you will, the more fundamentalist Hindus do not
believe that at all. And there's a real problem with fundamentalist Hindus running down, capturing
and kidnapping and executing people in India right now, um, of different faiths, including
Muslims by the way, and Christians. Um, but this is a, but certainly Christianity is pretty strongly,
though we hopefully are loving in the midst of it. We also are a exclusion, exclusive faith.
And we don't think there are multiple paths to God. Now God may decide to accept and have mercy
on whoever he decides to, that's different, but the only path to God is through Christ.
So we've had that, we've had that conversation.
Yes, we have. Absolutely. And why we believe that. Um, and so it's not exclusive in that anyone can
walk that path. Anyone can accept that free gift. That's the Christian view. Um, but,
but that is certainly not the case for Islam. Um, but like you're saying, I think it's not
have that boils down to if you're deconstructing or trying to reconstruct,
it seems like it is a gesture of like attempted kindness of like, yeah, just setting people at
ease, but inadvertently, yeah, is like insulting their intelligence in some way, or they're like
seeking of truth. Um, because it's basically like minimizing that in some ways, it's like
trying to encourage it, but it also could be viewed as minimizing it, which could be really
discouraging for someone who's like, no, like I'm convinced there's a truth out there. I don't know
what it is, but I'm trying to find it. Um, yeah, that seems like it could be really discouraging
of like, Oh, well then it doesn't really matter. Like I, I can just kind of settle on anything.
Yeah, I would be, I would be fascinated. It would be, this feels like one of those
efforts that Christians sometimes make at, at being friends with everyone that a hundred
percent of the time blows up. Like we're, we're, did, we're the seek. If there were any Sikh
Muslims, Hindus in the room, did they go like, Oh, well then, then we can just all be friends.
Cause the Pope, I mean, not, I don't mean friends. I mean, we all serve the same God. We can all just
worship together. I can start going to the Catholic church just as easily as my Muslim
church. Yeah. Like to the mosque, like, can I, can I go to the Catholic church then just as much as
the Pope going to start showing up at mosques and stuff. And like, we're singing with us and
worshiping with us and quoting the Quran with us. And I don't think anybody buys it. And maybe I'm
wrong. Maybe, maybe I'm being inappropriate about this. Maybe there's a lot of people in the world
who are comforted, like, Oh good, the Pope gets it. But I just have a hard time imagining that
there are many people who were comforted by the Pope's thoughts. It just seems from at least the,
the short Google search that we've done, at least people in the Catholic faith and voices in it are
like, Oh, okay. Well, let's just see what he means by the context of it, rather than like accepting
it as faith at face value. Yeah. I mean, like, this is actually super comforting. It's like,
wait, wait, wait, hold on. You, I just need, you need to listen to what he says. He's,
he is our leader, but then just decide kind of for yourself. Right. It's, it's, I don't know.
It's a quandary. Yeah. And by the way, in evangelical churches and Protestant churches,
that's exactly how we treat our religious leaders is what if they speak the truth, then we listen
to it and we follow it and we learn. And when they speak something that isn't true, we go,
yeah, just a guy or a girl like this. Humans are messed up that way. Um, and so just,
evangelical church has, has also gone wrong. Some of like, you know, whole churches or
denominations being led one way because they followed a man instead of God. Right.
Yep. That is doctrinally unsound, um, to do it that way. So anyway, this is, this has been an
interesting conversation and, and I just was curious, I don't know how many people have spotted
it. How many people have heard about it? It got covered, covered up. Sounds conspiratorial. It
vanished into the distractions of the rest of the world very quickly. But I think for us as Christians
and people dealing with deconstruction and reconstruction, it was worth a conversation.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith. If you enjoyed what you
heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info
at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist church.
Remember don't give up, trust God, search for answers.
